segments.text: I have two too louds, two too softs.
Well, how's this then?
All right?
We have to begin in order to get through our program and get on with the next sessions.
I have a few comments to make, and we have a few other brief comments, and then we'll get on to the major event, the Pilgrim Award.
I, of course, although it is the third day, want to offer an official welcome to you on behalf of the conference, SFRA 83, and also the Science Fiction Research Association.
We have among our midst not only you people, our members, but also a number of distinguished special guests.
We have some people from the local community too.
I want to mention a few of their names.
I think one of the things that made this meeting unique and different has been its participation and cooperation with the local festival, the Arts and Science Matrix Midland.
We have with us some people from Matrix Midland, and I'd like to introduce them to you at this time.
We had a science subcommittee that planned this portion of the program,
So if you didn't like it, then it's our responsibility.
If you did, say so.
But not yet.
Where is he seated?
Pat McCurdy, would you stand up, please?
Pat McCurdy and his wife.
His wife's with him there.
Pat and I and another gentleman, Richard Dalton, who could not be with us today, did the planning basically for this program.

But of course, planning would be nothing without execution and without the great resources and the great facilities available here in the community of Midland with the Center for the Arts and also with organizations like Matrix.
And we have a spokesperson here from Matrix who will say a few words and give you Matrix greetings.
And when I introduce her, I'd like you to not only welcome her, but also show your appreciation for Matrix.
She too is here with her husband, Herbert Doan, seated at the table here of Doan Associates in Midland.
And I present to you now one of the leaders in Matrix, Junior Doan, please.
Nice to see a crowd of your size in Midland.
I'd like to add my welcome to you all, to Midland, to Matrix Midland, to our fair community.
I hope you're all briefed by now that Matrix Midland is a 19-day festival of the arts, sciences, and humanities.
For a speech to Rotary, I researched 3,500 festivals, and I finally concluded that Matrix is unique.
What makes it unique is that we're trying to show the arts-science relationship, the arts-science blend.
Basically, I feel that's what science fiction is about, combining science and the art of writing to produce science fiction.
Certainly, science fiction is a blend of science, creativity, and imagination.
From earliest days, science fiction saw directions in science and projected them into the future.
Often, they proved correct.
Many of our creative people in Midland are avid science fiction fans.
Science fiction seems to appeal to the creative in at least a certain sector of the population.
However, rejection of original ideas, as you all probably know better than I, is common in many fields, in science, in art, as well as writing and science fiction.
I'd like to remind you critics
about what Frank Herbert said this morning.
I don't guess you were there, but he commented that his first Dune book was turned down 20 times before being accepted for publication.
That's a lot, huh?
The same thing happened in a different area in a different way to Professor Notta.
He developed a new theory of polymers, and he presented his first paper on this new theory to the American Chemical Society for publication.
It was rejected.
That might not mean anything to you, but the same theory later went on to win a Nobel Prize.
Never mind the difficulties.
It takes commitment and skill to be a scientist, a writer, or build a festival.

Just as science fiction writers and critics meet to share and help each other, Matrix has the support and effort of what I call our helping hands, people who like the idea of Matrix, who invest their creativity, originality, and effort.
Joe DeBolt is one of these hands and an important one, chairman of your research association meeting, co-chairman with Pat McCurry of the science fiction
program at Matrix this year, we depended on him and his very high level ability and the committee's high level ability to bring the program that I hope you have seen and will continue to go to.
In the same vein, one of the great things about MATRIX is that many groups in Midland play an active role.
We have as co-participants dozens and dozens of institutions.
I was talking with our table just now about some of them.
In addition to meetings such as yours, we've had an ACS regional meeting, the Turner-Alfrey Polymer Conference, which has just ended.
The Michigan Museum Association Conference is coming up next week.

the michigan dance association starts today the michigan weavers guild is uh weekend after this and now we have your own so we really appreciate your being here and and part of our terrific community and our special matrix midland and i hope you'll like it well enough to come back again thank you
Thank you, Junior.
And now I should say a word and thanks, too, to the Science Fiction Research Association officers and the fine cooperation we got from them in the planning and execution of the meeting.
And from this portion of the program on, I will turn over the program to our distinguished president, Patricia Warwick.
As I start, I know you will all want to join me in applause for Joe and Denise DeBolt and their staff for the absolutely marvelous job that they've done on this.
Science Christian Research Association is 13 years old.
And I've been coming for 10 years.
And for me, one of the exciting parts is the pilgrim banquet or luncheon, whatever it may be, and the presentation of the winner of the Pilgrim Award.
And we always have this suspense.
Who may it be?
And you look at who is here, is not in the program.
You try to figure this out.
and you're about to know the answer.
Let me keep you in suspense just a moment longer when I pause to invite you all to come to a reception after the Herbert Lecture this evening in room 417.
This is a hospitality room.
We'll have a bar, and at least up to the point, it will not be a cash bar but a free bar, and I hope you will all come and join us then.
Now, on to the Pilgrim Award, an award for
outstanding contribution to criticism.
Criticism is still alive and well.
If you were at the Jim Gunn conference, which I know many of you were for the morning session, you realize how lively it is.
I can remember 10 years ago when I attended my first meeting at Penn State and the critics and the writers got into a shout fest and we still maintain our high level of performance.
As a matter of fact, the chairman of the Pilgrim Committee is Tom Dunn, and I'm about to introduce him after this morning's session.
He came to me and said that he thought it would be appropriate for him to defer to A.J.
Budris and let him present the Pilgrim Award.
But I insisted, no, that Tom Dunn must do it, and so I give you Tom Dunn.
Praise then darkness and creation unfinished.
Colleagues, friends, every year since 1970, the Science Fiction Research Association has presented an award to someone for an outstanding contribution to the field of science fiction scholarship.
The first such Pilgrim Award was presented in 1970 to the late J.O.
Bailey, author of Pilgrims Through Space and Time,
a pioneering work published in 1947, the first full-scale academic study devoted to the entire genre of science fiction.
This year, we present the 14th award to a no less deserving pioneer, as you shall hear.
But first, let me take a minute to thank the members of my committee for their conscientious, informed, and often impassioned deliberation.
Make that always impassioned deliberation.
Val Bregge in Montreal.
Will McNally in Fullerton, California, Curtis Smith in Houston, and Carolyn Wendell in Rochester.
Good work.
Yes, thank you.
Good work, people.
My sincere thanks for a job well done.
And thank you also for the wisdom of this year's choice.
He's a courageous and principled man.
And he's a first-rate scholar, world class.
And he's made an outstanding contribution to SF scholarship.
And he's a decent man.
He's a kind man.
He's a mensch.
And he's a good teacher.
He's won three awards for meritorious teaching, including Teacher of the Year.
And as soon as I start getting specific here, you'll all know who he is.
A few more appropriate adjectives then, and then an end to the suspense.
He's tough and he's hard and lean.
He's worked in factories.
He's worked on tugboats.
He was a naval and intelligence officer in the Strategic Air Command, participating in operations involving spy missions over the Soviet Union.
He graduated magna cum laude from Amherst in 1955.
And soon after his three-year hitch, he got a PhD in English and American Lit at Stanford.
I see heads nodding now.
And was invited to stay on after his degree as full-time faculty, the first Stanford graduate so honored in 33 years.

In 1961, he taught one of the very first university-level courses on science fiction in the USA, disputably the first course, incidentally, and began a career as critic, scholar, teacher, social and political activist, which continues to this day without abatement to be astonishing and legendary in scope and volume and depth.
In dozens of books and articles, he has given scholarly attention to Hamlet, Renaissance drama, Melville,
Hawthorne, Darwin, Lenin, the youth movement, the Vietnam War, J.G.
Ballard, Lovecraft.
His anthology, Future Perfect, and now the cat's out of the bag, fair.
Future Perfect, 19th century science fiction, is, I am told, still the definitive collection.

In its field, but continuing on, The Politics of Literature, American Prison Literature and Prison Songs, Jack London, Fitz James O'Brien, Class Structure and the Teaching of English, The Need for Reform in Prison Education, American Plans for Space Weaponry, and in a jam of a book about which more later, Robert Heinlein, to hit most of the high points.
He has taught at Stanford, Rutgers, Connecticut Wesleyan, Yale, Venseramos College, the Free University of Paris, Johns Hopkins, and San Jose's Department of Adult Education.

He has refereed for some 25 university and scholarly presses, and his articles have appeared in over 60 learned journals, anthologies, and news publications, including The Futurist, Saturday Review, Science Fiction Studies, Extrapolation, Progressive Labor, The Washington Post, The Journal for the Society for the Study of Multi-Ethnic Literature of the US, The Chronicle of Higher Education, The Village Voice, and on and on and on.
And if you don't know who he is by now, you should kick yourself.
He has made over 100 public presentations in addition to this list and at more than 50 colleges and universities, and that's not counting an uncountable number of television and radio appearances.
Oh, yes, and he's made three films, including with Anthony Boucher and Ted Sturgeon, I believe, a history of science fiction for NET made in 1966.
Fellowships, grants and aids, awards have come his way and continue to come.
I said astonishing, didn't I?
I also said legendary.
How legendary?
Well, his early interest in the civil rights movement turned to growing concern over US Southeast Asian involvement.

And while many of us, to our later regret, waffled and tap danced circumspectly through the Vietnam tragedy, certainly through the early years for some, this English teacher threw himself headlong into the struggle to stop it and into the contemporaneous and growing movement for social and political change.
In 1966, he resigned his commission as captain in the Air Force Reserve in specific protest against the war.
Now an avowed communist, he debated the president of Rockford College on the hidden power structure of American universities.
And in the next five years, he published and lectured tirelessly on the war, the politics of revolution, the nature of American institutions, universities, foreign policy, and economic imperialism.
In 1971, he gathered together every major document from the student and protest movement and published them in a large, inexpensive, soft cover volume.
And though it was regrettably heavily censored, From the Movement Toward Revolution should be applauded by all those who cherish academic freedom.
As you well know, not all do.
Our award recipient was fired for his political activism.
His defense, The Real Issues in My Case, is the cover article of Change, the magazine of higher learning, June 1972, and this is better amplified in his autobiography.
Some regard this episode as just punishment, others as cruel, not to mention unconstitutional, martyrdom.
Either way, he endured it with grace and later prevailed.

and many far to the right of the far left now regard most or all of his stern criticism of american economics and government policies to have been justified a legend then of personal courage and political concern which testifies to his singular excellence in all this
Is all this relevant to his work with science fiction?
You bet your life it is.
He's never seen the inside of an ivory tower, or if he has, it doesn't show.

He integrates literature, politics, human and humane goals, his vast experience with America and Americans, and he pours it all into his tireless labors, which, in 1980, gave us a definitive essay on the massive canon of the dean, Robert A. Heinlein, subtitled America as Science Fiction.
is a brilliant study of, and I quote, lucid and trenchant analysis, in the words of a rigorous critic.
And again, quote, bristling with insights, end quote.
And here, it seems to me, is the harvest of his life.
Having paid heavy dues,
He has written a sensitive book without condescension or petulance, a forceful critique of American values by way of a thorough analysis of a major exponent of those values.
Written in a plain spoken, deft, clear-eyed prose, informed by vast erudition with deep roots in the American soil.
Okay, here we go.
For all that he has done for us, capital U, capital S, let us now praise Bruce Franklin.
Well, thank you so much.
I must say after that,
I'm sort of at a loss for words.
This is really wonderful, and that introduction is a hard thing to follow.
I wanted to talk some about what I see as the history of our field, some things that happened in the past,
what changed it, and where we are now.
And I was going to cite as an example of something that I thought was rather staggering, a minor little fact, but what was said about Frank Herbeck topped it.
That is, back in those primitive days of 1964, when I had Future Perfect pretty much ready to go, I submitted it to publishers.
It was rejected.
by 17 publishers, not as many as the 20 that rejected Frank Herbert.
But the interesting thing was the reason for the rejection, which in case after case will basically boil down to this.
There is a science fiction market and there is an academic market, and there's no possible way that you can put the two things together.
They're absolutely incompatible.

Well, by around 1965 or 60s, no, about 1960, I'm sorry, 1968, it finally got published in 66, around 68, 69, some of those same publishers were writing to ask if I would do a book for the academic science fiction market, which I guess we represent.
Well, by 68,
I think, and certainly by now, would pretty much won the battle.
The war, maybe.
I guess there were still battles going on.
Science fiction now is essentially a fixture of the American academy.
It is part of the environment.
We are no longer, for the most part, considered the loonies and eccentrics that we were looked on back in, say, 61, 62, 63, 64, 65, when we first started teaching science fiction courses.
It's a lot easier to get things published now.
we no longer have to legitimize the existence of our field.
That is, I think, generally regarded as some kind of legitimate thing.
Although, of course, those of us who are in colleges and universities know the kinds of attacks that it is subjected to by people who have very different values about what literature is all about.
That's in the academy.
And part of the reason, of course, is because the importance of science fiction itself
can now hardly be in doubt.
I think that any thinking person in America today knows that science fiction forms part of the center of the imagination of our entire culture, for better and for worse.
So that our job now, I think, is very different from the job back in the, let's say, 58, when the science fiction seminar first gets started in the MLA or the early 60s.
It really is no longer essentially a job of legitimizing our field, legitimizing the serious study of science fiction.
We're in the maturity of our field now.
We need to define, to distinguish certain things.
And essentially, and this is really the main theme of what I'm going to say, our role is now critical in every sense of that word.
And we really ought to think about what that word means to us.

Let's think, just to get some perspective, of some examples of science fiction within our culture, not necessarily the things that we pick up in the bookstore that are labeled science fiction or the movies that we see that are labeled science fiction.
I think it's safe to say that the most expensive piece of science fiction which has been produced so far is Epcot.
It's a billion-dollar center, the experimental prototype community of tomorrow, that ultra-optimistic science fiction created by some gigantic multinational corporations of the 1980s.
Wall Street itself echoes with rhetoric and visions and slogans, consciously evoking the wow, gosh, thrills of the most simple-minded science fiction.
Focus on the future is emblazoned across the top of a full-page futuristic electronic environment advertising a new institution with the most ironic name.
It's a little over a year old now.
The New York Futures Exchange.
Dean Witter Reynolds asked us to put our own present and future wealth in the hands of what it calls its team of futures experts called, capital T, capital F, the Futurists.
The Kansas City Board of Trade advertises itself with a jazzy logo and the slogan, the future is here.
Northrop shows itself as a futuristic city under the bold heading,
Northrop engineers in the 21st century.
The science fiction hype of high technology corporations becomes so frantic that they themselves begin complaining.
This is a quote from the New York Times of April 28, 1981.

We still haven't licked the Buck Rogers problem yet, says James L. Donovan, Coherent, this is Coherent Radiation, used to be called Coherent Radiation, Coherent's chief financial officer, referring to the struggle of Coherent and many other laser manufacturers to overcome the science fiction image that has been created for lasers as exotic, powerful, and dangerous devices.
Curious, that sounds a little dated now, two years later, the reasons there were.
We heard something about it last night.
We'll hear something more about it in a little while.

While billions of dollars pour into the video game industry with its ecstatic visions and thrilling beeps of global, cosmic and universal combat and destruction, other billions are taken out of our paychecks to finance the militarization of space.
which is sold to Congress and the public with the most bizarre and implausible science fiction scenarios.

And we're still paying for the science fiction visions that we could conquer Vietnam by utilizing an electronic battlefield, people sniffers, and chemical warfare weapons exotically labeled Agent White, Agent Blue, and Agent Orange, which I guess brings us back to Midland.
I have a little cluster, a little cluster right out of the middle of 1980.
This is the science fiction environment in which we live.
The first is a quotation from an investment bulletin called High Technology Investments, April, May, 1980.
These little companies have seen a vision of the future and have set out to capture it under the leadership of a few brainy, vigorous, and worldly people.
The values being tested are technological wit, courage, stamina, greed, and glory, right out of the 19th century, plunging into the 21st.
Here's one from the New York Times the next month, June 18th.

The Central Intelligence Agency's secret experiments on new methods of espionage have included using trained seals and otters, monitoring the bioplasma fields of agents, and testing the sonar of electric fish, according to documents newly made public.
The experimenters also worked on developing such weapons as a poison pellet, electric stun guns, calibrated blackjacks, and marshmallow barrages.
The intelligence agency's research and development staff was also interested in the secret life of plants, peace pills, and an array of other futuristic scenes.
Two months later, at the Democratic Party convention, then President Jimmy Carter, in his acceptance speech, projected two alternative science fictions as the core of his acceptance speech.
His governing metaphor was that there were two futures.
There's a quote from his acceptance speech.
The president is the servant of today, but his true constituency is the future.
That's why the election of 1980 is so important.
It's a choice between two futures.
Children born this year will come of age in the 21st century.
The time to shape the world of the year 2100 is now.
And then he gives his own, the future he represents, a future of confidence and hope and a good life, blah, blah, blah.
And then the other one.
But there's another possible future.
And that other future I see despair, a world of tinsel and make-believe, a fantasy world.
Same month.
Wall Street Journal has an article on what to them was a new phenomenon, video games.
Quote, video madness is sweeping the country with flashing colors, booming explosions, nerve-tingling action, and little electronic monsters like the invaders from space that adorn this article.
And there we were in the day pages of the Wall Street Journal, a little...
the little critters from various video games.
Of course, that was all this 1980.
And for most of the Wall Street Journal readers, that was then news.
That was before some of those readers would be investing billions more dollars in the video game industry.
By 1983, this year, a few months ago, March, we see how fast and far we came just on that little front in three years.
It's about President Reagan's headline.
Reagan says, video games provide the right stuff.
President Reagan had some kind words for video games, which he said are helping to train a new generation of jet pilots.

Mr. Reagan, speaking to a group of math and science students at the Walt Disney Epcot Center here, said video games have helped many young people develop, quote, incredible hand, eye, and brain coordination.
Mr. Reagan said, computerized video screens resemble radar screens in jet cockpits.
Watch a 12-year-old take evasive action and score multiple hits while playing space invaders, and you will appreciate the skills of tomorrow's pilots, the president said.
Well, of course, that is part of what we see really, I think, as a contest between two different forms of science fiction having to do with space.
I did an article...
It appeared in the beginning of 82, called Invasion of Space, about what was developing along the lines of the militarization of space, which

Battle stations in space bristling with energy beam cannons, hunter-killer satellites firing grid-like projectiles too tenuous to be targeted, swarms of automated space mines shielding orbited command posts that direct squadrons of diminutive space cruisers.
Well, this kind of scene that once gave respectable science fiction a bad name
is now part of the future being planned for us.
A different kind of science fiction in which the human race matures, unites, and together explores the cosmos now seems less probable than it did just a few years ago.
As recently as 1975, US Apollo astronauts linked up with Soviet Soyuz cosmonauts in a handshake that momentarily made space a zone of scientific cooperation

and even friendship but today the u.s program for scientific exploration of space has been almost entirely usurped by a program for the military exploitation of space high place pentagon officials now talk of possible space battles between the united states and the soviet union sometime between 1990
Well, see, the interrelations between our field and all this, the actual environment we as human beings have our existence, I think, is pretty obvious.
Maybe there's some other things that are less obvious.
I presented a paper in December at the MLA about late 19th and early 20th century science fiction, the construction of the myths.
that have a lot to do with our culture.

And it focused quite a bit on Edgar Rice Burroughs, who, after all, when we think about Star Wars and so forth, I mean, Burroughs was the one who really got the whole thing of subsidiary rights and all the little animals and creatures and so forth and the t-shirts and candy going as science fiction adds a multi-billion dollar spin-off industry.
I talked about Burroughs' particular vision of the world and how the myths in Burroughs have their influence in our culture.
Then, when was it?
Oh, it was just a few months later.
Again, it was March 83.
People probably saw this article in Parade, What Famous People Read.

uh and they and they interviewed the president reagan about uh his reading uh i realized all my reading left me an abiding belief in the triumph of good over evil uh and what was the main thing he cited edgar rice borrows his quote from president reagan not only his tarzan stories but also his science fiction john carter of mars the warlord of mars all the john carter books
There's another kind of relation.
It's interesting how little we have taught, even here, I know there's going to be a panel on this tomorrow, but so far, about what is, after all, the number one fact of our existence.
The fact that with our science,
Having delved into the very forces that constitute matter, we have now created the ability to exterminate at least human civilization as we know it, probably the human race, many times over.
Now, there's been some very interesting writing on the psychological effects of this, because we know that...
In order to function in our life, it is necessary for us to screen out a lot of information.
We have to narrow the information that comes through to our consciousness.
Part of this process has been called a process of numbing parts of our mind to all the data that are constantly coming in as input.
And one of the striking phenomena about a world enveloped in nuclearism with this threat to our existence
is so much of that is screened out, that this numbing does take place.
In the classroom I had a most startling

demonstration of this, giving a quiz on those, and they've just read some short stories this week, and I usually give just a brief quiz before we talk about things, so they get to say something before I do.
One of the stories was All You Zombies.
Another was I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream.
And there were only three students in a fairly large class that saw the nuclear bomb in either of those two stories.
And of course, they're central in both.
There are many critics of science fiction writing about all these zombies who don't see exactly how important the bombs are there.
So this interface between the literature we teach and the living environment in which we have our being is not a trivial matter.
We too, I think, do a lot of numbing
in our own consciousness of what it is that we do with science fiction.
Let's go back to that time when science fiction was winning its acceptance as something more or less respectable.
Why was it then?
What were the special historical factors then that made it?
I think 68's a good date, if we're going to pick a date.
It's a little questionable to pick an exact date, but 68's a very good one.
And I think the 68, I'm sure most people here remember, what was there, talk about a sign of the times.
No, Judith Merrill remembers it.
The advertisement in Galaxy and then also elsewhere, I think it first appeared in June 68.
And there were two lists of people, one on one page, one on the other, 72 on one side, 82 on the other, all science fiction writers.
72 said, we the undersigned believe the United States must remain in Vietnam to fulfill its responsibilities to the people of that country.
And the 82 on the other side said, we oppose the participation of the United States in the war in Vietnam.
That was the context of 1968.

was the year in which the modern language association finally allowed us in the science fiction seminar to have this big forum at MLA, which was very well attended, really marked the stamp of acceptance on what we do.
I remember I was chairing that forum, but there was a problem.
And that is, there was also a big sit-in in the same hotel because Louis Kahn, if people remember this, had been arrested for putting up a poster with scotch tape on a marble pillow.
And I had to kind of shuttle back and forth between the sit-in and the forum.
Now, were these unrelated events?
Was it just by chance?
that science fiction began to be recognized as something very important to our social experience in this particular time, and especially in 1968, maybe the year right before and right after?
Was it coincidence?

that at the very same time that science fiction was getting accepted as something which belonged in the university, that other forms of popular literature were also being accepted, that literature by non-white people was for the first time getting into the curriculum of the universities, or rather the first time since the 1930s, that literature by women began to be looked at?
Or was there something that had happened to our society that made us even...
us academic dummies who had been brought up largely on new criticism made us realize that literature had something to do with the world in which we live.
We have claimed too little for our field, but our claims, I think, have also been indiscriminate.
And partly they've been indiscriminate because we were trying so hard to make things seem
legitimate, academic, respectable, and working within the university environment.
And remember, this was the university that came out of the 50s.
This wasn't the university of the 1930s.
This was the university that came out of the 50s, working within that very straight environment, trying to make people see that science fiction was so important.

Well, we were guilty of a lot of things, of being very defensive, apologetic, trying to use the style of our colleagues and our professions, that obscurantist style, in order to make what we did seem to be just as legitimate as what the other people did, and so on.
But we have won.
There's no way that science fiction is going to be removed from the curriculum.
It was wonderful news to hear the size of this organization, which has now grown to over 400 dues-paying, card-carrying members.

And I think it's very predictable that the organization is going to have a healthy future, that science fiction forces are going to continue to proliferate in the colleges as they have in the high schools.
I'd go further, though.
I say we've claimed too little.
I think that science fiction courses may be, or to be more precise, could be the most important courses taught in literature departments.
I would make that claim.
I think that science fiction courses
could be the most important courses taught in literature departments.
And I would bet that probably most of us here who aren't academics secretly believe that, whether we admit it to our college colleagues or not.
Because when you think about it, most of the supposedly great literature that we were trained in was about relatively trivial concerns compared to the concerns of science fiction.
We get back to this word critical.
The really critical questions, the crises of our age, what it is to be a human being in the waning years of the 20th century, what other literature really deals with this?
Martellus.

who also began a course in science fiction in that 1961-1962 academic year, wrote an article in 1974 in the College English Association chapbook called Science Fiction, The Academic Awakening, which I think was called The Science Fiction Course Reconsidered, or I'm sorry, Some Thoughts on the Course in Science Fiction, and he had written an earlier article.
And in that, Marx said this, quote, I have a great sympathy for these traditional interests
and hope that there will always be room for them in colleges and universities.
Well, that in itself is a very interesting statement.
You begin to say, well, maybe the shoe's on the other foot or something.

And as most of us know, one of the reasons that science fiction courses do arouse considerable animosity among some of our, quote, colleagues is that their courses are there languishing with three or four students while
We can't find rooms big enough to teach the science fiction course.

There are other phenomena, too, that most of the traditional courses, the students who are in that course do not include any students except for some graduate students who really are readers of that literature.
Whereas anyone who's ever taught science fiction knows you get a fair number of people in that class who are real readers of that, really read this stuff.

Well, Marx said he has sympathy for these traditional interests, hope there'll always be room for them in the colleges and universities, and goes on, it would be a sad day for all of us if there were not.
And frankly, I would hate to see Arthur Clarke replace John Milton, but we need not make this either-or kind of choice.
He says, I would hate to see Arthur Clarke replace John Milton.

and then he goes on what i'm expecting someday is a work of the magnitude of paradise lost which seen in the context of its time we could describe as at least akin to science fiction like paradise lost this major work of science fiction
will present a coherent vision of the universe and man's place in it and the ultimate meaning of it all.
Now, Mark Hillegas wouldn't want people reading Arthur C. Clarke in place of Milton.
I don't really think that that's the adequate comparison.
I don't really think that that's the choice, if there were a choice to be made.
The comparison with Milton is all off stapleton.

There is the imagination who took the latest scientific understanding of the cosmos in which we live at that time, and it hasn't been modified that all much since then, peopled this cosmos, took that cosmology and peopled it, tried to present
an imaginative construction adequate to the scientific knowledge of the world in which we live.
